title: Bring on the Summer … and the Stares!

content: As a child, my parents taught me that it was rude to stare at other people. Now, as an adult who’s traveled to numerous countries, I’ve realized that children are not the only ones who need to learn this lesson.
Whether it’s because of my darker skin color, my hair (usually worn in box or knotless braids while traveling), or my scars from breast cancer treatment, I’ve received stares all over the world.

To be clear, I think there’s a difference between people staring out of genuine curiosity and staring out of rudeness. While neither is particularly appropriate, I’ve gradually learned to decipher between the two.

The first time I noticed people’s stares was in middle school. I got my ears pierced when I was in 5th grade and developed a keloid on the back of my ear a few years later. It was not only physically uncomfortable but also visually unappealing.

My peers would always ask me, “What’s that?” Sometimes I’d wear my hair down or cover my ear with my hand during class to make it less noticeable. I eventually had it surgically removed in 7th grade, which was a huge relief – until it grew back. This time, it was smaller and didn’t bother me as much because I’d given up on wearing earrings, and it wasn’t noticeable enough for people to continue asking about it.

content: In more recent years, the keloid scar from my chemotherapy port has also been a source of stares and conversation. Given that it’s right below my collarbone, this scar is most noticeable in the summer when I’m wearing dresses, swimsuits, or short-sleeve tops.

Apart from being itchy at times, its appearance doesn’t bother me. Instead, I view it as a reminder of everything I’ve overcome and as a way to educate others when I’m inevitably asked, “What’s that?” – as if I’m back in middle school.

This summer, I have two new keloid scars that I’m already anticipating will spark conversations. After my sarcoma removal surgery last year, I was left with a long, straight scar across my back and a large, round one on my left breast. The back scar is where my plastic surgeon took tissue for reconstruction.

content: Initially, he planned to make the incision diagonally, which would have resulted in a more noticeable scar. I’m glad I advocated for myself and requested a horizontal incision instead, as it is now easily covered by my bra line. The scar on my left breast is from the removal of the tumor and the surrounding skin, followed by reconstruction with the tissue from my back.

content: A few weeks ago, I was traveling internationally and became painfully aware that people were staring at the round scar protruding from the top of my sundress. I felt very uncomfortable and vulnerable walking down the streets, knowing that people’s eyes were on me.

However, I realized that this is just something I’m going to have to become accustomed to, as the scar isn’t going anywhere in the foreseeable future. I’m not ashamed of it by any means, and I actually think it’s fascinating how my breast was able to be reconstructed in such a manner.

So, although I might receive more stares than usual this summer, I’m ready to use them as an opportunity to answer, “What’s that?” with more grace and confidence than my middle-school self did. Each stare now represents not just curiosity or rudeness but also a chance to share my journey and educate others about the power of self-advocacy. I hope to foster understanding and empathy, encouraging others to look beyond appearances and appreciate the stories that make us who we are.
